name: Self-Hypnosis
summary: A self-directed mind-body practice using focused attention, relaxation, and autosuggestion to influence psychological and physiological states for therapeutic benefit.
description: Self-hypnosis is a cognitive-behavioral and mind-body technique in which individuals guide themselves into a hypnotic or trance-like state for therapeutic purposes. It typically involves relaxation, focused concentration, and the use of positive suggestions or imagery to achieve specific goals such as pain reduction, stress management, or behavior change. Unlike therapist-guided hypnosis, self-hypnosis empowers individuals to apply techniques independently, often after initial training. Research indicates efficacy for pain control, anxiety reduction, sleep improvement, and habit management, although outcomes depend on suggestibility, practice, and guidance quality.

setting: Clinical training followed by independent practice
treatment_duration: Short-term: daily or several times per week for 2–8 weeks
Ongoing: as needed for stress management or behavioral goals
metadata.training_required: Initial instruction by hypnotherapist or structured self-hypnosis program recommended; can be self-learned with proper resources
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated; often taught by hypnotherapists or through wellness programs

contraindications: Absolute: untreated psychosis, severe dissociative disorders
Relative: severe depression or psychiatric instability (requires professional oversight)
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe when practiced appropriately; mild risks include drowsiness, emotional release, or reinforcement of negative suggestions if poorly guided.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate – supported for pain, IBS, and anxiety; mixed evidence for habit control and other uses.

sections.text: Self-hypnosis involves entering a trance-like state characterized by deep relaxation, narrowed attention, and heightened suggestibility. Neurobiological studies suggest involvement of altered brain connectivity between prefrontal regions and default mode networks, decreased activity in the anterior cingulate cortex (pain perception), and modulation of autonomic responses. The use of positive autosuggestions may reframe cognitive and emotional patterns, enhancing resilience and symptom control.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment, comfortable position, clear intention or goal, optional script or recording.
procedure: Relaxation induction through breathing or visualization.
Introduction of autosuggestions or guided imagery related to goals.
Gradual re-orientation and return to normal awareness.
sections.frequency: Daily or several times per week for best outcomes.
sections.total_treatment_time: Typically 4–8 weeks of regular practice for measurable results.

short_term: Decreased pain perception, reduced stress, improved sleep
long_term: Enhanced coping, improved quality of life, sustained habit change with consistent practice

rare: Worsening of psychological symptoms if misused in unstable psychiatric conditions

relative: PTSD with unresolved trauma (use trauma-informed approaches)
special_considerations: Training or initial instruction enhances safety and effectiveness.
Should complement—not replace—professional care in serious conditions.

ideal_candidates: Individuals with chronic pain or stress
Patients motivated for self-care and behavior change
Those seeking non-pharmacologic strategies for insomnia or anxiety

concurrent_therapies: Sleep hygiene and behavioral health practices

sections.typical_session_cost: Low cost (apps, recordings, self-guided practice); $50–$150 if taught by therapist
sections.insurance_coverage: Rarely covered unless part of professional hypnotherapy

items: Self-hypnosis can be taught in clinical or group settings, then practiced independently.
Evidence strongest for pain and IBS, with growing support in stress and sleep.
Compliance and motivation are key predictors of success.
Should not be considered a substitute for medical or psychiatric treatment.
